Looking through the anime titles that I had chosen to watch and review Youjo senki or its English equivalent which is sage of Tanya the evil sits high on my list. With the premise of an interesting setting, theme and capable voice cast as well as what promises to be an interesting take on a conflict that is modeled after the first world war I can say that this anime drew me in immediately and I must say I was impressed by the result. 
Youjo senki is a war/action anime that has pseudo historical elements within its story.  This review has a chance ofminor spoilers so please be aware. 


Youjo senki takes place in an alternate world and in a time and setting that is roughly an equivalent to the world as we know it during the events of the first world war. In this alternate world, the empire a country that is located in the center of the continent that it is situated in is engaged in a number of wars with the surrounding countries. The year is year that this story takes place in is roughly the 20’s. In this war, the empire though a sizable country that has both a powerful military and a sizable industrial might to back them up is fighting a war against several enemy factions that are each worried about the power that the empire has been building up. In this case, one can see that the empire is largely based on WW1 era Germany based not just on the titles that its officers have but also the names of its characters. 

The empire finds itself facing the combined armies of three different factions which is the Republic, The Entente alliance and the allied kingdoms respectively. Here the republic is loosely based on the French republic for bases of their character names and the name of their capital while the Entente alliance is based on countries of the Scandinavian peninsular like Denmark and Norway. Lastly the allied kingdom is based off the UK. The other major powers like Russia and the US are present but only provide logistical support to the main powers. 


Technology wise the combat between the armies makes use of largely weapons of WW1 era which in this anime includes bolt action rifles, large artillery guns, machine gun teams, WW1 era fighter and bomber aircraft and of course the infamous trenches that made WW1 so different to other wars. The one aspect that Youjo senki introduces to the combat is the introduction of magic and those that wield it which are called mages. Unlike mages shown in other anime the mages here unleash their spells not by use of wands but learning spells that they unleash through the aid of a computation crystal. This allows them to unleash their powers through both their weapons in the case of attack spells and Armour for defensive spells. Apart from attack and defense spells mages are also able to use their powers to achieve flight and it is this combination of spells that make mages so powerful in this world. As a result, mages are elite troops due to the low number of them within all armies and though part of the regular military are treated differently. 


The idea of using an alternate version of WW1 era Europe as the setting for this series I felt was good and interesting as this is a setting that is seldom seen. By having the main character and her men fight for a faction that many would see as being the bad guys we get to see what would have happened if they through the use of smart and well thought out plans and strategies and magic manage to defeat the powers that are arrayed against them and win. A large what if scenario if you will. 


Tanya 

Tanya Degurechaff voiced by veteran seiyuu singer Aoi Yuki of Gosick and SAO fame and is one of the main characters of this series and is the protagonist of the series. A soldier of the empire and a powerful mage whose abilities are such that she is called the Devil of the Rhine by the empires enemies that she faces on the battlefields in which the empire fights its war with. Due to her latent magic power as well as her intelligence Tanya was promoted rather early in her career and as a result she is often underestimated by both allies and enemies alike due to both her age and her height. Her unusually low height makes her look more like a child than an adult which is often used for comical purposes in the show. Personality wise Tanya is a ruthless, calculating and cunning person that cares only about herself and her advancement in ranks. In the beginning, Tanya after joining the military only had a limited amount of things that she wanted and cared about which for this phase was to stay away from the frontlines and stay in the rear where she will be safe. 


Due to circumstance, she ended being put in more and more dangerous situations eventually being assigned to the frontlines themselves. Apart from being ruthless and calculating Tanya is also a smart person and a capable strategist and tactician and is able to come up with ingenious solutions to problems and at the same time come up with smart tactics to deal with sudden battlefield situations. Tanya also demonstrates the ability to always see the big picture of a situation which I find admirable within a soldier and a unit commander at that. 


Although ruthless and cruel Tanya is not without any positivity as though she still treats them harshly Tanya does care about the men that serve in her battalion willing to both motivate them and guide their growth as soldiers as well as shoulder any extra burden that she feels that they shouldn’t have. One notable trait of Tanya is her bluntness in that she is not afraid to express what she thinks of both the people that she encounters and the actions that they take. This is something that I thought was nice to see as all too often military officers tend to gloss over their plans and not worry about or consider actions that may affect them. Having someone who is both smart enough to understand the plan and be blunt enough to express their opinions of it without fear of censure is a good thing I felt. Another notable trait of Tanya’s is her speeches which though all are motivational tend to be quite dramatic though they almost always have the intended effect. 

Tanya, I felt was a well-designed character and I felt that her seiyuu veteran seiyuu singer Aoi Yuki really did a fantastic job voicing the character of Tanya. 



Visha 

Viktoriya Ivanovna Serebryakov voiced by veteran seiyuu singer Saori Hayami of the irregular at magic high school and Owari no seraph fame is one of the main characters of the show. A second lieutenant within the empire’s military and a member of Tanya’s rapid response battalion Viktoriya who prefers to be called the name Visha serves as Tanya’s second in command. Personally, wise Visha is a kind-hearted person that cares about the well-being of her comrades and will take the time to get to know them when given the opportunity and as a result she is well liked among the battalion. Visha is also an honest and dutiful person that prefers to tell the men everything that she knows about a mission and hates hiding details from the men. 


Though easily intimidated by soldiers of higher rank than she is and not having the bluntness of Tanya Visha is still very much loyal towards her friends and comrades and has great trust in not just them but also in her commander Tanya’s judgement and actions as well. Because of Visha’s personality she serves as an effective second in command to Tanya in that she contrasts with Tanya’s personality’s brash and ruthless personality with one that is kind and caring towards anyone that she meets. Though not as powerful as Tanya in terms of combat ability Visha is able to hold her own in most fights and at the same time keep up with Tanya’s fast flying speeds quite easily proving that she too is a capable soldier and mage in her own right. I felt that Visha was a well-designed character and I liked how she had a personality that was the opposite of Tanya’s. This had the effect of minimizing the risk of Tanya turning everyone in her unit against her by being her usual self as Visha will be there to stop her from going too far. This contrast I felt was a good move on the studio’s part. I felt that Saori Hayami really did an excellent job portraying the character of Visha here. 


Erich von Rerugen 

Erich Von Rerugen voiced by veteran voice actor Shinichiro Miki of Bleach fame is one of the main support characters of the show and is a high-ranking officer within the empires strategic HQ. A capable soldier and an expert strategist Erich is an honest, measured and cautious person that is also methodical with his plans in that he tries to account for every action that the enemy can take in each situation before submitting his plan. Erich and Tanya can be said to be enemies in that Erich is the only person within the empire that see’s Tanya as a monster in the form of a little girl while the others see an extremely capable young officer that is proven in bravery and combat. However, it’s important to note that although Erich despises Tanya he still respects her combat prowess and intellect and is often surprised on how well her unit fights on the frontlines. Though in the beginning he saw her as a monster as the series progresses Erich starts to develop some respect for Tanya and by the end of the series has some faith in her. 



Arts and animation 


Arts and animation for the series I felt was well done with the character designs and the design of the various environments being especially detailed and well done. The designs of the uniforms that were worn by the characters of the various factions I felt was impressive. The combat scenes that were in the series I felt were pretty well done and detailed with the fights themselves being both frantic and enjoyable. The animation for the use of the magic that was used in the series I felt was also nicely done. 


Voice acting 


Voice acting, I felt was particularly good in this series with Aoi Yuki who voiced Tanya and Saori Hayami who voiced Visha doing a great job voicing their characters. Aoi Yuki in particular I felt really managed to portray Tanya really well able to switch Tanya’s personality at will to reflect changing events and emotions. 



Music 

Music for the series I felt was pretty good with the opening and ending themes being my favorites. The scene music that is used for different scenes also felt appropriate for the given scene. 


Overall conclusion 

Overall I really enjoyed Youjo Senki as it had an interesting story, interesting setting, a great cast of characters and a capable voice cast. Using an alternate world that is modeled after the first world war I felt was an interesting setting as this setting is not widely seen or explored within anime. 


One advantage that this brings is that it allows the studio to feature both the actual countries that took part in that historical war and at the same time impose the anime version of events into it. I felt that the various factions that were in the show which as explained earlier amounted to three main blocs which was the allied kingdom, entente alliance and the republic respectively was well thought out and designed with each being pretty unique. The Empire which was the main faction in the show was also well designed and thought out. One result of using an alternate earth as the setting for the series is that it allows the development of an original storyline in which events that did not happen in actual history can be explored and the effects of those happening can be visualized. In this I thought it was interesting to see the empire despite being surrounded on all sides by powerful enemies and not have one ally still emerge victorious despite having to fight on multiple fronts. This was not just as a result of Tanya and her unit’s contribution but also in the plans that were drawn up by HQ most of which I found to be interesting. Being a military themed anime the main point of the story is of course the participation and involvement of the main character and their contribution to the overall story which in this case is the war. In this I felt that Tanya and her men despite numbering less than a battalion is able to field both the firepower of a much larger unit and at the same time have the maneuverability of smaller units and with this affect the course of the war by being sent on specific and critical missions that allow the empire to secure many advantages against their opponents. 


In terms of characters I felt that both Tanya and Visha were both excellent characters that were well designed and developed characters that had rather interesting personalities. Tanya in particular while having the appearance of a little girl who looks way too young to be a soldier is nonetheless an extremely capable soldier whose high latent magic gives her the power to unleash many devastating spells that when combined with her other combat skills makes her a powerful soldier that is capable of going against multiple foes at once. Tanya’s skill in battle is matched with her personality which while ruthless and unforgiving towards her enemies is caring towards her troops though this is not something that she would reveal to others. Visha however is different in that her personality is a contrast to Tanya’s in that she is both kind and caring and actively looks out for the men under her command. In the relationship that these two have though Tanya is the superior officer Visha is subordinate whose personality helps ensure that Tanya’s ruthless personality does not get out of hand and that the unit is still able to do their jobs. 



Voice acting for this series I felt was especially strong with Tanya’s seiyuu Aoi Yuki and Visha’s seiyuu being pretty impressive. Aoi Yuki in particular deserves a lot of praise as Tanya is not the easiest of characters to portray as she has many different personality traits that though making her stand out makes portraying her difficult. In particular, I really liked how Aoi Yuki was able to voice Tanya’s speeches as I felt that the speeches while motivational were also resounding and had conviction in them. Whether in battle or outside of battle i felt that Aoi Yuki really managed to do a great job here voicing Tanya with this role being one of her standout roles in all the roles i seen her in.

Imagine a reality in which the world's most power hungry nations battle for control and dominance in classic WW1 style. Now include the fact that these nations have troops capable of flying through the skies with almost magical abilities and weapons and you are sure to turn some heads. Now include the fact that a loli is a major for one of the most powerful mage battalions and I may have just broken your neck. As strange as this concept sounds, I found it even more strange how good this show turned out to be. Here's my full overview for Youjo Senki: 
Story: 8
As Istated before, yes; a young girl who looks younger than a middle schooler is in charge of a massive battalion of mage-like warriors that dash through the skies as a superior form of air artillery. Their goals range from them demolishing their foes on the ground to the ones lurking in the heavens with them. The one who leads is Tanya Degurechaff, a once male salaryman that is reborn into a little girl thanks to the best/worst, all-knowing entity known simply as God. Struggling to maintain a peaceful upbringing in her new world, Tanya battles the enemies of her nation and the plans that this God has set forth for Tanya.


All in all, pacing matters little as the story is always about the war and how close the Empire is to securing a victory. It is very simple to follow as long as you focus on the situation at hand. Every episode delivers a battle where the strategy is logical and makes sense. No holes, just war and the motives that follow it. 


Art: 7 


I very much liked the art style in this show. It's not basic enough that you see it often in other shows. The best scenes are obviously where the action is. Seeing Tanya zip through the air striking down mages with her bullets, bayonet, or magic was a "blast". Aside from the action, Tanya's emotions are delivered very well. When you see her angry or upset, you truly see and feel it. 


Sound: 6


I see the sound in this as average only because nothing was really memorable. I always skipped past the opening/ending songs so no tune were favored by my ears. If anything, the sounds of war in this are fairly nice. Whether it is the cannons going off, explosions being set, or the clanks of tanks making their way across the ground. Everything seemed good, just not amazing. 


Character: 8


Okay, listen, I have a knack for evil MC's and that is exactly what you get here with Tanya Degurechaff. There are no stupid, cliché traits that plague her like countless others protagnoists. She is focused, determined, and is as serious as your dentist. Honestly, Tanya has very little backstory but she does not need it here because all that matters is where is trying to go. There are no plot holes about her that leave you scratching your heads either so she is very simple to follow. I'll say this, don't get attached to the character but her ambitions. 


Besides Tanya, you'll constantly see the faces of Tanya's strategic leaders and the mages that take orders from her. I found most of them to be okay and that's about it because I've already forgotten their names. 


Enjoyment: 8 


Being only 12 episodes, I did find the show to be enjoyable. I found Tanya to be very entertaining and I was curious about what obstacles were bound to stand in her way. I eagerly waited for the clashes between her and God and how Tanya's perspective on it and life would change. 


Overall: 8


Just watch it, it's good. I've not kept up on the news for a second season but the ending implies one. When it drops, I will be there to see what I got from the first season: a whole lot of vintage-looking battles and a loli ordering the troops around. Paradise.

Story 8/10
The story could have used a little more context you're kinda just thrown into it with no beginning to it, but you find your self enjoying her struggle between her and being X.
Art 10/10
This art was visually amazing and made love to my eyeballs. Very well done.
Sound 9/10 
Sound fit with the effects and made sense to what was happening on the screen. Music could've been cool but need the less was still cool.
Character 8/10
Tanya was an amazing character, the other characters did not stand out as much as she did, nor did I have as much enjoyment with them as I did her.\n\n
Enjoyment 10/10\n
This anime was very enjoyable for me. I haven't seen anything like it so it was new to me and really nice.\n\n
Overall 9/10\n\n

"The Saga of Tanya the Evil" is an "isekai" anime, meaning like Sword Art Online it's about a character who lived in our world until he or she is transported to another, more fantastical world. The story of this anime I am awarding a 9/10 just because of how unique and batshit insane it is! Get this: an evil salaryman living in modern day Japan is murdered by a disgruntled worker he fired, only to piss off God (whom our protagonist calls "Being X") in the afterlife and deny his existence. A vengeful God then punishes our main character by reincarnating him as a littlegirl in a war-torn fantasy world not unlike our own 1940's Germany. Tanya decides to make the most of her situation, so she joins the military, rises through the ranks, and basically tries to conquer the world! If this show reminds you of anything else, let me know, cuz I think it's pretty DAMN UNIQUE!


If I were grading this show on the character of Tanya alone it'd be a 9/10. Tanya Degurechaff, the Devil of the Rhine, is the focus of this show and she really is the main reason to watch it. Tanya is that rare anime protagonist who is a totally remorseless villain, yet is still a total treat to watch! She's so charismatic and intelligent, you can't help but want to follow her evil exploits.Think of Lelouch from Code Geass or Light from Death Note. Whenever Tanya freaks out and curses God or chews someone out, that is when the show is at its most entertaining! Still, all of the other characters get very little focus and even Tanya's best friend, Viktoriya, gets little to no character development. There *are* some good moments, like when Tanya convinces to her classmate to drop the program because he's a family man with a daughter Tanya's age, or that one Republic soldier who becomes obsessed with killing Tanya after she steals the special gun his daughter bought for him, but these are few and far between. The side characters get around 7/10 compared to Tanya, so overall I'd give the character score 8/10.


The art in this show is well done, 8/10. The backgrounds are very detailed and beautiful, and action scenes utilize 3D models in a way I've never seen done better in anime. I'm surprise because studio Nut (yes that's the name) is a brand-new studio, and for its first anime, Tanya us exceptionally well made. Character models look good (especially Tanya's insane facial expressions), except when they don't. For example, there are plenty of times where I thought Viktoriya looked cute and pretty, but there were just as many scenes where she had this derpy fish face that made me cringe.


Sound was very well done in this show, 9/10. Listen to this show with headphones and you'll feel like you're on a battlefield due to perfect sound effects. The music in the show is also great, the OP Jingo Jungle (apt name) stuck in my head for days. I'll also mention here the EXCELLENT English dub. I started watching in Japanese, where Tanya's voice was also very good, but I switched to English for Monica Rial's A+ performance as Tanya! Rial played a similar villain named Maria in Witchblade, and she's just as perfect for Tanya because she so effortlessly switches her voice back and forth from cutesy to crazy. Seriously this show is worth watching just for Monica Rial!


My enjoyment of this show is an easy 10/10 but your mileage may vary depending on how much you enjoy crazy anime girls and action/explosions. I *do* think the action scenes were exceptional, like those sky surfing battles are some of the best in anime. I also really enjoyed the subtle, dark humor in this show. For example, Tanya actually just wants a quiet, easy life, and a military career is just a step towards getting that safe desk job. What's funny is that Tanya does *too good* a job on the front lines, so she keeps being sent back into combat over and over! Another running gag is Tanya is afraid of secondhand smoke (something they haven't even heard of in this world), and then at every strategy meeting her superior officers are always chain smoking.


Overall, Saga of Tanya the Evil is a crazy show I'm giving 9/10, though your mileage may vary depending on your tolerance for extreme violence, blasphemy, lolis, and wartime imagery.

Youjo Senki, or as it has been translated into English, The Saga of Tanya the Evil, (which is particular, and will address later) is a piece of alt-history fantasy. Our main character is a Japanese salaryman living in the current day, who has rejected God, and after being killed by a former employee, out of resentment for having been laid off, is told that he must accept God in his next life. This next life is where the story begins, in the year 1925, during The Great War, but not quite the same as the real one. The biggest major difference, as you can probablygather, is that the armistice wasn't signed on the 11th of November, 1918, and the war has continued, mostly in the same manner as the real Great War, with the exception of the fact that as it turns out, magic exists in this universe, with Mages (Tanya being a major one) who are able to precisely send artillery strikes onto targets, as well as stop getting hit, and other magical things. It's also worth noting that the country names are different. The German Empire (the country Tanya fights for) is 'The Empire', the US are the 'Unified States', the UK are the 'Allied Kingdom', all of which mean little to me, beyond France, who are the Entente Alliance. I won't go over this too much, but could they have chosen a worse title? It'd be like if it took place in the Cold War, and Germany was called the NATO Warsaw Pact.  

And so, Tanya, (who's a 13 year old girl unlike most the officers who are just middle aged men, by the way) must find a way to end this stalemate and win the war for the Empire. And this is the highlight of the show, since the action is all very well orchestrated, and it uses the setting of WW1 more as a backdrop than as something it attempts to actually emulate, there's never an intertitle telling you she's in Ypres or the Meuse-Argonne or anything, but it's just muddy trenches and villages in Europe so they all look pretty much the same, and it's probably more DAK than Imperial German Army with the fact a lot of it isn't emphasised on the trenches, which isn't a complaint. Still, that's not to say I have no complaints at all in regards to this. Mages are capable of sending surgical strikes onto their targets with ease, so surely this would be enough to have a major change to the trench warfare system, if not the abandonment of it. After all, what actually caused it was the combined arms Blitzkrieg, predominantly utilising planes and tanks, both of which are used in the show. But no, it seems like soldiers in this universe are told to sit in a trench and wait for someone to charge over the top, and if some flying loli comes up with something that I can only guess is a G43 (a magazine-fed semi automatic German rifle, which may be anachronistic but the Unified Kingdom had M1 Garands so if they don't care about historical accuracy then I don't) then just accept your death. 

So, to get to the point, it's about our titular character Tanya, who is evil, it even says so in the title. But is she really? She might be an extremely staunch atheist, even in the face of supernatural happenings, which isn't particularly evil, but neither are her actions. I know a thing or two about Patton and Guderian etc. (i.e. important military personnel from the 1910's onwards), and she really doesn't strike me as that different to any of them. If I had to describe her philosophy in a sentence, it would be getting the mission done at any cost, but she didn't do anything especially wrong in my opinion, even in one of the later episodes which I felt was meant to make the viewer perceive her as Hitler or something. Perhaps it's because we're so used to anime protagonists being absolute beacons of moral behaviour, and never doing anything bad, and so I was in the wrong mindset, expecting her to slap a shell-shocked soldier or firebomb Paris or something. At the end of the day, she's not that great of a protagonist. She's better than what we usually get, and I'd rather she's as she is than some Shinji Ikari, but I feel like the author rested a lot of the entertainment value on her being a great character, which I didn't think she was.


So, is Youjo Senki a bad show? It really isn't, and of many instances of moe-isation of war, this does strike me as one of the better ones, but it just could've been so much more, and I suppose it's like some WW1-era artillery. It tries to hit many things, but fails to hit any. A show about the Great War, a show about magical powers, a show with an amoral yet compelling protagonist. It tries to be all of these, but doesn't do any with that much finesse. It's not a bad show, it's all well made, but it's certainly not one I plan to watch again any time soon.

First things first. My "reviews" system is explained on a blog entry. Which can be found through my profile.
------
✦Story
The concept was pretty interesting. Having modern day salary man who climbed up in society for peaceful life, but his lack of human heart/soul and being too much of a so called "logical, rational" person became his downfall. Story of revenge, hatred, conflict, mankind and gods playground.
I found for the most part the idea of the story pretty interesting.
But the minus side of the story for me is the whole more serious military topic, patriotism, soldiers and such in general. As I personally despise military in reality,then even in fiction more "realistic" presentation of such things are a big turn-off for me. So that was a big minus for me plus how old smart ahems farts sit behind the table and play game of chess with life. So this is strongly minus for me simply because of personal reasons.


Another big plus of the story was the whole concept of mighty being toying with our protagonist and I guess the big picture will be in this story the goal of making main character gaining the human "heart".


Although another issue with the story would probably be lack of development or progress in characters themselves. It felt that story was too focused on war and tactics than the actual story.


To sum it up, story is pretty interesting and for the most part the plot and development of the world is great, whilst character focused story is quite slow.


✦Art & Sound

Art its superb. Action is pretty amazing. Aerial combat was pretty amazing that at some point it even became pretty much of a matrix. Design choices are great. Overall art was just great, but it missed a little bit for me to be truly amazed or impressed. Thus won't get full mark from me.


Before I move to OST, I will mention sound effects in general. I found the balance of music and sound effects very impressive. In a sense it felt as playing battlefield with war tape mode. Meaning that sound was quite spacious, rich and fulfilling/immersive. Now to OST. Music was generally absolute bliss, a lot tracks were very tense and fitting. And the way they made music fade into background of action and make it suspiciously quiet during some of the more dramatic and tense moments, was simply spot-on.


Pretty impressive sound.


✦Character

Middle-aged society drone with lack of human soul gets body of yohjo. That alone is impressive. Seeing the adventures of young sociopath in the fields of blood was darn impressive.


Aside that quite few character very somewhat interesting, but more of annoying or just plain stupid. It's world filled with battle and military mania. Thus we have lot of human chess players. But at the same time making them unlikable and showing cruelty of humanity for silly reasons is pretty nice thing to see now and then in Anime.


On top of that I found the characters good in more of a objective way. But personally aside full on mad sociopaths, I didn't really care much about characters. Having crazy characters is entertaining enough for me.


To summarize, in sense of enjoyment characters are varied and are for the most part quite interesting. 


✦Enjoyment & Overall

I did mention my main complaint in story section as it connected the most to that part.


Will add that I did quite enjoy overall, ended up binge watching in a day and even though I initially gave it 7, whilst writing this review I noticed no much I play around the weight of "personal enjoyment" in scoring. The average would be still 8 worthy.


Thus I will give this show 8 as very good Anime with few issues plus a little personal complains I had about it.

What's that? You say you want and Evil, German, loli, flying around and killing people. This is definitely the show for you. I will talk about at least the first two episodes in this review. Ep. 2 is where the hook for the show is, so I would recommend watching them before reading any in depth reviews. 
The story is somewhere between WWI and WWII. However, it is set in some fantasy reality. So it is not really those wars. One big difference is that the major battles are fought in the sky, by psychically/magically propelled and armed soldiers. 
To make things more interesting weseem to be placed in the evil conquering empires POV and following a little girl named Tanya. Tanya seems to excel at focusing her powers during combat, all the while being evil as heck and loving it. In the second episode, we find out that Tanya is actually the forced reincarnation of a ruthless businessman. Forced by some sort of god, that is salty because the MC will not acknowledge the gods existence, even on deaths doorstep. So now Tanya has to make the most of her second life. All the while, struggling against a crafty god. 


The art in the show is pretty good and the actions scenes are flashy and full of weight. Some shots are done in CG animation, but these are usually wide shots or when a group of soldiers are flying. The character design is also kinda of generic except for the MC and her head subordinate. Everyone else is generic soldier-man.


Outside of the Tanya and her subordinate, there are only a few other characters that get characteristics. One of which comes a little later in the story and would basically be the hero protag of a different anime, who sees Tanya as the evil boss Character. 


Overall, I highly enjoyed this show. Sometimes the show can slow down a bit. However, knowing that there is usually a climactic action scene or Tanya being evil at the end of some (sort of) boring episodes, can help keep the viewers interest.

If you want to watch something about world war 2, military strategies, and philosophical/moral questions about humanity and God, you should watch this. 
I skipped the first episode because it was so boring, but the episodes that came after were more promising. The story is interesting because the theme is about how far one can get in life as a "devil" in world war 2 (or was it 1) setting and what obstacles you would meet.
The only character you end up caring about is Tanya, the main character. I find every other character as superficial overused personalities. She is quite a relatable character and youend up wanting to root for her. 


The OP and ED is great. They are both worth listening to. The voice actress of Tanya is a famous one and definitely helps with making the anime more interesting. Her voice acting gives Tanya the kind of depth and attention she needs.

The art is pretty normal. It seems like the kind of artwork a normal studio produces. 


Overall I gave this anime an 8. The episodes don't end in a cliffhanger and neither do they give much thrill. The way the author recreated World War 2 centred around Tanya was what made this anime worth watching.

What if we take Light Yagami and make him a young girl with magic powers fighting a world war?
That's basically what this anime is. Taking place in an alternate universe where the world is on the tipping point of its first world war, this young girl takes up arms to bring her glorious country to victory.
Of course, an average anime of this type would be little fun, seeing wars fought with a couple of magic users is an old concept and rather boring at this point, so this anime takes everything a step further. Our main character, Tanya, hates god because she is an absoluteatheist, and this being that claims to be God just wont stop messing with her, until she finally admits defeat and admits that God is real and everything is going exactly to his plan, which paves the path for the never ending stream of hilarity that is this girls 1v1 fight against god himself.\n
The series has a pretty good set of supporting character, including:\n

Guy with scar above his eye: He is just this guy that shows up often with a scar above his eye but is important because he survives getting stabbed\n
The people in Tanya's squad: Just your average memorable characters that are immune to bullets because plot protection\n
High ranking officer 1: He has weird hair and hates Tanya, but doesn't do much.\n
High ranking officer 2: Actually talks to Tanya, embraces her good war advice and uses it to make himself look good\n

[not many spoilers, i'll keep it vague] I'll start off by saying that Youjo Senki had quite a lot of potential. One of the main reasons why I started this series was because I felt that its premise was interesting and unexpected - an atheist salaryman reborn into another universe as a girl, participating in a world war? You don't find that in most animes, so kudos for that, i guess.
The most problematic area, in my opinion, was character motivations and relationships. To me, Tanya's motivations were never clear at all. She did say that all she wanted was the 'climb the ladder in therear' and not go to the frontlines. But at the frontlines, she displays aggression and an enthusiasm for violence that contradicts her statements from before. This is especially problematic as this is a very character-centric anime. This means that the plot revolves around Tanya, and her rapid-response battalion. If her motivations aren't clear, then the plot is essentially devoid of investment on the part of the main character. Furthermore, there was a lot of potential in terms of relationships between characters. For example, her relationship with the female war veteran that follows her everywhere could have been more well-developed. What do they think of each other? Why are they paired together? What about her and her battalion? There are some scenes of camaraderie, but nothing to outrightly suggest that they have much loyalty to Tanya. 


The plot was also problematic, in the sense that it kept pushing for pay-off, without the set-up required. This is an anime about war. That entails really dark and heavy themes, of death and destruction and bombs. However, we as viewers usually don't get invested in the war and violence at all if we aren't emotionally invested in the the characters. In other words, the deaths of unnamed characters usually fail to incite any emotion in a viewer, unless the story has "set-up" our investment in the character. Okay, to be fair, they did try in a few instances (can't say, spoilers), but it wasn't enough, and at most they spent about a minute on it? There wasn't enough time spent to make sure that we understand and value these characters, and would be sad if they died. Thus, despite the constant emphasis on a "world war", I didn't feel much for it. Furthermore, there is quite a lot of patriotic talk in the anime (like,, everytime someone important opens their mouth). However, the anime only 'tells' us - instead of 'showing' us - that the consequences of losing this or that battle would be bad. Of course, anyone would understand that losing battles and seeing people die is bad, but reality is that depicting a successful operation in the face of all odds doesn't leave an impact the way failing and seeing your men die does. Then again, 12 episodes aren't enough time for all that set-up, though it does pay-off quite nicely in the end. (See: Kuroko no Basuke and the Inter-school competition)


The art was quite good though, I particularly liked the way they depicted the battle scenes, though the way characters were drawn kind of put me off. Music was okay, not amazing, but okay. 


All in all, not very worth watching, but still pretty enjoyable. The ending is a pretty good twist (and a perfect set-up for a next season heh)

This was my first war/military anime, and I must say, I was quite entertained all the way through. I found it a welcome change from my usual genres and may consider rewatching it in the future.
~Should you watch it?~
- Story:
The general idea is pretty easy to follow, but may seem complicated at some points. It mainly just follows the rising of the main character through the ranks and the war progressing.
- Characters:
The main character is really the only character with a unique personality. While the others do get character development, their personalities tend to be the same. The main character is also the only oneto get a real backstory.\n\n
- Action:\n
Youjo Senki isn't 24/7 in-your-face action-packed, but certainly a decent amount. Action scenes involve guns, epic blasts, and death and/or destruction.\n\n
- Violence:\n
If like me you aren't fond of a lot of gore, this anime isn't too bad. It isn't incredibly graphic, although there are a few occasions when a character is 'pumped full of lead'. Apart from that, blood is generally a common sight - it is a war-based anime after all.\n\n
- Humor:\n
There isn't much humor to be totally honest. It is a pretty serious anime, although every now and then there might be a little something funny, but don't expect anything 'hilarious'. The anime itself remains pretty strong and enjoyable even without humor.\n\n
Apart from all that, if you think you like the idea of a cute, somewhat psychotic, lethal little girl being in the army and killing people, definitely give this anime a go.

EY, YO WHADDUP IT'S MY MOST ANTICIPATED ANIME OF WINTER 2017. Now, let's have a one-sided discussion on Youjo Senki by the studio with the best name for hentai.
Story: Could've been better with the setup. 8/10
This is the second most interesting part of the entire show. You would think after seeing the PV and reading the synopsis that this would be based mainly around major action set pieces, but the main focus is on the cause and effect of each strategic decision, as out main psycho is almost all-powerful due to her circumstances. The true enjoyment is in the psychological skirmishes and setup in thequieter scenes, with the execution and situations in the thick of the battles being the reward for all that thinking and foresight. Normally, this would be boring, but the characters and the inherent nature of the military and each soldier's ranks and specialties allow for some interesting and exciting situations, while still having room to point out how seriously (NOT PG WORD) the entire setting is. On top of that, any instances of asspulls or bull can be explained by SONZAI ECKSU just pulling some strings willy nilly to mess with our salaryloli, while still allowing there to be tension and an idealogical conflict between the two due to the specifics of their beings, if that makes sense. However, there is one specific instance of bull near the end that I could not be satisfied with, even if it means we might get more Youjo Senki.


Art: Inconsistent, but managed to impress me around the end. 8/10

The only character that has a notable design is Tanya herself, but that's almost the point. She strays from the more realistic (not realistic, just more so comparatively) designs of literally everybody else due to the nature of her personality, which is one of the more out there ones in recent anime history. Whoever designed, animated and directed the shots of Tanya when she goes full crazy elitist loli all deserve medals, as they are SPOT ON. The animation has a few highlights in the first two episodes to reel you in, but the last two episodes kick it up a notch not only in the animation quality but in direction as well, as there are a few more interesting things done visually compared to the rest of the show. The CGI rages from actually bad to decent in a few places. The middle of the show is not as interesting of technically proficient as the specific episodes I mentions and rely more on the dialogue and characters, which I'll get to, of course. The explosions are notable due to how much impact they portray and how awesome they look. The OP is actually terrible, with 40% of it being footage from the show just thrown in there with no meaning, unlike what was done in 91 Days' OP with it's slick, meaningful editing. The original footage of Youjo Senki's OP also has little meaning, and the last shot of Tanya watching a sunrise is not at all appropriate to the tone and focus of the show. The only semblance of theming is with the clocks in the early part of the OP. The ED is nothing but stills with little meaning, if any, but I have a feeling it was less due to incompetence and more that the few high quality, stylish stills and the song were supposed to carry it. It's a 6/10 in my eyes, which, considering it's an ED, is pretty good, if only when you compare it to most others.


Sound: WOAH, IS THAT A LITTLE BLONDE GIRL OR A FIGHTER JET? I CAN'T TELL, THEY SOUND EQUALLY AWESOME. 9/10-Hypothetical blind man watching anime for some reason


God bless the soul of whoever made the mages and their weapons sound so amazing. OP and ED songs are both perfect. Jingo Jungle plays to the strengths of Tanya's character (by which I mean the trait that most people notice the most from the PV), but as I said earlier, the visual aspect of the OP didn't take advantage at all. The ED song was by Tanya's VA. ED songs by cast members is usually a good sign that the VA(s) had a blast portraying the character, which, since Konosuba 2 is an example, is a great thing. However, I cannot give this a 10 due to the lack of standout performances from most of the other cast members. The VA for Ajin's Satou does a great job with his Zettour, but the only other standout is Serebryakova's VA, who was slightly above good.


Character: SHE IS THE DEVIL IN THE FORM OF A LITTLE GIRL. AKUMA DA/10-IGN Japanesesalaryman% freshness-Rotten tomatoes


The best part of the show, no doubt. I'd rather not explain her backstory, actions or ideologies, as I think it's best to just see for yourself. I just think it's best to point out that she's not as insane as the PVs or the people who watch this show make her out to be. She's much more intelligent than that, which makes her outbursts even more cathartic. The other characters are good, specifically the generals and that blue haired guy I quoted. However, the other characters, including Serebryakova lack any depth, especially when compared to the standouts, with at least one of them being nothing more than a plot device, albeit one that both makes sense and enhances some of the conflicts and themes, while also showing how much of a hindrance SONZAI ECKSU will be in the future.


Enjoyment: I expected more, but was satisfied with the last two episodes. 8/10


Overall: an 8 that should've been a 9

One of the best anime of winter 2017. SPOILERS BELOW!
The story is about a salaryman who gets reincarnated into a loli named, Tanya Degurechaff, after being killed by an ex-employee that he recently fired, and meeting a being who claims to be God but Tanya calls him, "Being X". The reason for being reincarnated like this was because the salaryman was atheist and had a lack of faith towards the employee he fired.
The era Tanya was born was in an alternative timeline of WWI where magic exists. She was born with outstanding magic capabilities and was recruited for the Imperial army and behaves like noother heroine.


As the story progress, Tanya starts to believe in Being X as he helps her defeat her enemies by giving her more power. There were times where Being X would mock her as well.


The art quality is unique compared to every other anime I've seen.


The sound quality in this anime is amazing. The opening, Jingo Jungle, by one of my favourite bands, Myth & Roid; the ones that did the second opening song for Re:Zero, is great.


The characters in this anime are unique with a few generic like some of soldiers.


Main:


Tanya Degurechaff: A former salaryman who was reincarnated as an intelligent loli that's a jerk and becomes a soldier. She ranked up to Major quickly.


Viktoriya Ivanovna Serebryakova: An second lieutenant who's optimistic, friendly, and carefree soldier. She works right under Tanya.


Supporting:


Adelheid von Schugel: A mad scientist! (my Okarin reference) who was a former atheist and his experiments in weapons didn't work well with Tanya until Being X made him believe in him.  


Erich von Rerugen: Vice Director of Strategy and Operation. He's very passionate, sensible, and sincere about his country. He was also against Tanya's promotion and has a complicated relationship with Tanya.


Hans von Zettour: A Brigadier General in the Imperial army. His believes and mindset are outstanding. He's like the brains behind the Empire's success.


Kurt von Rudersdorf: Another Brigadier General in the Imperial army. He is always seen smoking a cigar.


Both Hans and Kurt are friends as they went to the same War College.


Weiss Matheus Johann: The vice captain of the Tanya's 203rd Aerial Mage Wing, and the captain of the Tanya's 2nd Aerial Mage Squadron that belongs to the 203rd.


Being X: Some invisible being that claims to be God.


I enjoyed this anime a lot. I love the fights and characters in this anime. My favourite part was when Degurechaff pretends to talk like a playful little girl when communicating over radio to the workers of the Dakia factory then starts an attack on the factory while the workers are laughing. The only thing I didn't enjoy as much is the story as it can be confusing at times.


Overall, I give this a 8/10.

This is a MUST watch!

That is what I love about anime they are not always predictable like most movies that use the same story and ending over and over.  As for the first season it ended well and here is hoping for season 2, I would really like to see where the take the story. Due to description and premise sounding really obscure and strange and in addition to that I would be Studio NUT's first anime I had real doubts that this would be anything. But I was gladly surprised to find out that this would be this good. Concept of grown man reincarnated into a parallel universe WWI Prussia is kind of absurd. And to be honest I am no a huge fan of military animes. With this anime I am willing to make an exception since they really  know how to make working story and chars. TLDR: A pretty interesting but poorly handled idea wrapped into ok action, extremely ruined by unnecessary edge.
(spoiling out only episode 1 and 2)
We start off at episode 2 where the plot instantly presents a very interesting idea of Rational vs Emotional. On one side we have an over the top rational guy that won't believe in god even if one appears in front of him and on the other side we have the guy that was driven into a corner, which ended up murdering him and the god (or being X).
This was a very intriguing start and what I liked the most about it isthat the main character didn't lose his s**t even facing a situation like this, showing again to which extreme he's on the Rational side.


Now this is where my very first problem with the show appears - the fact that what I said above is episode 2.

This looks like a small detail, but in reality the first episode is the one that tries to appeal the most to the audience (aka the hook). So we learn here that the hook of the show is not the interesting above mentioned conflict, but action and edge. Also, it has a psychological effect to set the main hero in your brain to the loli...


And daaaamn the edge gets annoying as hell at points. Not only that the thing is aesthetically extremely displeasing, but it conflicts the very main idea of the show by taking off the Rational side of the MC, turning... it... into a typical sadist.

The most obvious next complain is - why a loli?

I am 100% positive that giving the MC like 5 more years wouldn't damage anything in the plot, so the obvious remaining answer is - to please the edgelords (sometimes... really.... fu Japan...). And again it makes no sense within the theme of the show! When the MC is so interested in just securing his easy life, he should have just chilled out for as much as possible. I am sure he would be provided an ok life, considering the importance of the mages in the setting.

These two things are actually the biggest flaws in the show and damage it from multiple aspects. If you can get over these, then your experience with it will be a lot better than mine.


Now the logical question that follows is - how does the show handle its core idea and does it go anywhere with it? The answer is - kinda...?

If you look at it on a superficial level - yes. This whole thing is like a game to the being X (going to call it that, it cracks a smile on my face), which constantly sets up bad situations for the MC, at some points making it even look like trolling and watching the MC struggle can be very entertaining at points.

But again there's this thing that keeps bugging me... Being X is the biggest a**hole in the series. In the Rational vs Emotional fight, I'd really like to see both positives and negatives of both sides. In the Rational camp we can see them both: negative - can't understand human emotions and pays for it; positive - brings results. Yet in the second camp there's only an ass that keeps making wars and killing off people just for the sake of fking around with one person and not only that, but gives power to that person so that it stands a chance so that the killings continue. It's way too easy to take a side.

I have to say that I'm not trying to nitpick this, because it really doesn't take that much effort to show another side of X - just a few scenes here and there where blessings save life. Then it would perfectly symbolize what Emotions are - sometimes warm, sometimes self-destructive.

In the end we have to blame the laziness of the scriptwriter and the low demands of the audience.


The last thing one could care about are the characters... and we have literally one. Everyone else is of low to no importance and the only opposing force in the form of an actual character will exist in the sequel.... YAAAAAAY!

I also generally tend to hate on "perfect" characters. I'm talking about Narsus from Arslan Senki or the MC from Alderamin etc. This is the category that the MC of this show falls into. All the judgments he makes are always corect and his logic has no flaws, being dragged down only by others, even to the point of unjustified hate, despite the MC having the right predictions.


In the end, it's as I said before. Watch this for some action, ignore the rape faces (unless you're into this kind of thing) and try to not too dig too deep into the plot. This is a decent time-waster, nothing more nothing less.

"Deus lo vult"...
*****    Some minor spoilers ahead!   *****
On first impressions, LA thought this anime would be showing how Tanya, an ace in the Empire's army would open up to her cohorts within the war with Viktoriya being her clutch back into "humanity" due to Tanya's obsession with killing and violence, however this notion was QUICKLY revoked as it didn't become "fixing Tanya's behavior and opening herself up", instead changed to her rivalry towards "Being X" or GOD and just her survival in this new world wrought by war, all due to Tanya's previous life as an atheistic salaryman about todie and was reincarnated by Being X through a wager and Being X doing everything in his power to both make Tanya "respect" the gods as well as making Tanya go through hell and back in times of the war, THAT was kinda what cemented LA into both carrying on watching this anime and very quickly jolted to one of LA's favourite anime of Winter 2017. Sure it's sorta a blend of both "protagonist is OP" (but only through Being X's interferences...so slight twist there on this trope) and "transported to another world", but blended soo well all due to Tanya's motivations and just her primary goal of both sticking it to Being X and surviving "this life".


After that...it drove too deep into the war commentary perspective instead of focusing on the major plotline at hand, sure the entire war and Tanya trying to get into the rear echelons is her entire goal and Tanya allowing herself to shoot herself in the foot AND allowing the war to go into world war level was Being X's cause, but the anime's meat is just showing more war commentary than the conflict between Tanya and Being X, which was the best element in the anime and it's not an exact "faffing around", but LA just wanted to see more of it and kind lost it's maniac, sadistic anti-heroism it had in it's earlier episodes, LA still liked the series and like last season's Shuumatsu no Izetta, it went down the same route in terms of plot format, just exchange yuri fluff with war commentary without our main protagonist as it's focus. HOWEVER if there is a bit of defense in all this, this is more build up to Being X secretly planting his own plan to throw Tanya off through both the war and driving Tanya deeper into it AS well as creating a new rival for Tanya.


LA doesn't need to say much about characters as the characters are minimalistic in some sense what with Tanya, Being X, Empire's Military higher ups like Hans von Zettour voiced by Houchuu Otsuka, Kurt von Rudersdorf voiced by Tessyo Genda and Erich von Rerugen voiced by Shinichiro Miki  as well as Tanya's own troops of the Empire and Viktoriya Serebryakova voiced by Saori Hayami. Yes, LA's favourite character was Tanya followed up by Viktoriya only if by default due to their screentime, but LA's more interested character was Being X himself but his screentime is VERY limited if anything and he works "behind the scenes" if anything. In terms of character development, Tanya gets the majority of it what with being a character-focused anime and everything, thing is, due to how the anime shifted from a resurrected person vs. GOD to...war commentary, she kinda lost some character development and she just still kept her sadistic nature, Viktoriya isn't much better as she's a bystander to the war conflict let alone a character without much power to the proceedings. The Empire's military higher ups are stereotypical to say the very least but the only character within that group to have some relevance to Tanya was Erich only because he is suspicious of Tanya. The characters if anything is shaky especially if you want to root for Tanya or see her fail, LA was in both parties for that.


In terms of animation by NUT, the animation was rather top notch if albeit slightly shaky due to some animation's quality dipping ever so slightly at times, though the battles were not one to be affected...completely, still the battles were some of the better animation fronts. The character designs were decent at best what with the animation going crazy with Tanya's crazed facial expressions, the rest of the character designs were at best ok but had some semblance of "who's he again?"...especially concerning Tanya's forces sans Viktoriya (that or trying to remember their names were just difficult to remember). Nonetheless, the animation was above average even with it's dip in quality at times and for NUT's first foray into a full length anime especially one this ambitious in it's animation, it's worthy of praise, quality and all.


In terms of voice acting, the voice cast is very good on both the Japanese as well as it's FUNimation Dub. In the Japanese, LA just LOVED Aoi Yuuki as Tanya and Saori Hayami as Viktoriya, like match made in heaven especially Aoi Yuuki as Tanya (it had her perfect range of loli and sadistic). On the FUNimation Dub side, Monica Rial as Tanya had perfect cadence for Tanya in similar respects to her Japanese counterpart and this too for Jeannie Tirado for Viktoriya as well. What can LA say?, this voice cast as minimalistic as it is, is excellent on both fronts.


On the soundtrack of Youjo Senki, LA will say BOTH the OP "Jingo Jungle" by MYTH & ROID and the ED Los! Los! Los! by Tanya Degurechaff (Aoi Yuuki) were LA's favourites of this season respectively (to the point LA has been listening to BOTH songs on loop at times). As for the OST, they fit the mood perfectly, LA had a special affinity towards the latin chanting battle OST prevalent in most of the battle scenes that it had it in.


The finale brought back Youjo Senki to it's former glory AS well as using it's military war commentary to it's best advantage in the form of Tanya's increasingly cynical view on war and humanity towards it and how she just wants the war to stop by ANY means to the point of raving cold-blooded insanity to smite God. The finale also brought on some new plot points and makes sense due to this being an ongoing light novel it opens the gates to a second season?...maybe?. Nonetheless the ending brought back the magic from it's earliest episodes and LA pretty much had a positive reception on this ending if it had the hinting at a second season!.


Youjo Senki put an interesting spin in the entire resurrected in a new world fantasy world especially when it came to our anti-hero main protagonist in whether you rooted for the sadistic loli or wanting to see her fail to her detriment of her resurrection placed on her by God as well as her conflict with GOD, but it got slightly lost in the war commentary it had going for it, until the final 2 episodes where the focus was back in which it redeemed itself...albeit slightly. Again this situation Youjo Senki fell into was similar to last season's Shuumatsu no Izetta even down it being about magical military warfare with female leads. By going into more comparisons and differences, they both have great starts then they start faffing around away from the major plotline then making up for it for the finale, the only difference between the two is the atmosphere, Shummatsu no Izetta being more optimistic, Youjo Senki being more pessimistic about it all. 


Even with all it's faults and how it disappointed LA in how it went into this direction, LA still liked this anime to allow this anime to STILL be in LA's Top 3 of Winter 2017 albeit barely (it got third place if your wondering) and wasn't nearly as a big disappointment as Shuumatsu no Izetta was.

The saga of Tanya the Evil (Saga) is a show based in an alternate world that closely resembles WW1 Europe. Saga initially aired in January 2017 at the time I was unaware of the show, later when I discovered its page, I passed on watching the show as the critics convinced me that Saga would not be worth my time despite its relatively high score. Fast forwarding to this season and Isekai Quartet is coming out. I had watched 4 out of the five shows featured and was curious as to Saga again in preparation for Quartet. So I found it and watched it dubbedonce I found there was one available. 


	One of the things I did like about Saga was its setting. The World War 1 setting is a neat period of history that until recently was not touched upon as much as the other great war. That is not to say they were going for sheer periodic accuracy; it is very much just based in that period. The big twist to the setting is that in this universe Magic exists, and the nations in the world use it to bolster their military might. Saga doesn't show many applications of this magic. We learn that children are tested for mana while young. If they have enough mana, they are sent to become mages. They channel their magic through crystals broaches pinned to their chest which allows them to fly and/or imbue their guns to shoot bullets as devastating as artillery or track multiple targets and put up shields to resist enemy fire. I don't think they show magic doing anything else though I think at one point Tanya throws a fireball, I absolutely could be wrong though.  Its something Saga does not go into any real depth about. I often wondered how this magic affected this world's history but with the way, not quite Germany generals talk about famous battles in Earth history like Hannibal's or Ceaser's remains unchanged leading me to believe that magic must have been a more recent discovery. Again I may be wrong, but Saga does not go into detail to refute that. 


	It is honestly one of my significant issues with Saga was that it never really goes into detail much.  I get they only had 12 episodes, but the show loses a lot by being this vague. I would have loved to get more background info on not quite Germany, almost France, The UK's sibling, maybe Norway, approximately Serbia or Burgundy, heck we did not even get to see much from Nearly Russia. This lack of information carries to most of the characters too besides Tanya, her adjunct, and the generals in strategy. The viewer is just not given enough to care about these characters nor many defining traits to differentiate them from other soldiers. 


		The cast as I mentioned is a bit lackluster. Tanya the main lead is not likable, but she really was not meant to be. Before she was reincarnated to this world, she was a manager of some sort at a company, a bit higher up than the typical salaryman. Tanya was a callous and cold man. He was a ladder climber with dreams of upper management for a comfy life, something she strives for even in her new world. Tanya is a person who hates inefficiency and incompetence at the start of the show we see him firing someone for not meeting their quotas. There are some excellent points to Tanya. The troop she trained that have passed muster in her eyes she values much and makes sure they are taken care of. Though part of me believes this is just because it would reflect poorly on her to her superiors if she lost men.  She also reminds me a bit of a lawyer always finding ways to skirt around or justify her actions to international war law. Her adjunct Visha is a bit of an airhead she is well-meaning enough and smart enough to command a squad of men, that and Visha clearly is the fanservice character as her rack is plentiful. The generals were a bit fun they had all the traits of their WWI counterparts with lots of drinking and smoking big cigars while they directed the troops throughout the war. It would have been nice to see more than the glimpse we got of the opposing sides generals, but it was fine as it was. Also, Tanya kills an opposing mage, and his daughter who has fled to for the most part USA signs up to fight against Tanya is named Mary Sue I chuckled at that.


	It does bring up a good point though I was surprised at how egalitarian these countries were. As opposed to their counterparts who just had women enlisting in support roles for the most part these countries do not discriminate whether a male or female wants to join active service. Now, this could only apply to the mages as they are a privileged class and a resource these nation states do not want to squander. Now that I think of it I did not see much in the way of female grunts, but more on background later.


	The battles and tactics employed were pretty cool to watch. I also liked the tech they gradually used some of it was later WWI tech towards the end.  There were some subtle fact references sometimes too. In one moment where Tanya is facing an enemy mage, he uses a trench shotgun. Something the Germans called out the Americans in WW1 as illegal because of their effectiveness at sweeping trenches. Something Tanya does as well. 


	Art-wise for the main cast, it looked average, but when it comes to the big battles sometimes, the CG looked really rough if there was a vast mass of people moving.  It was neat to see each nations motif for their mages. They all were individualized. I laughed when I saw the UK's Sibling's mages were riding mostly broomsticks. In the sound department, nothing stuck out. I mentioned I watched this dubbed and they did an excellent job I liked  Tanya's English Va better than the Japanese one.



	In the end, Saga turned out to be okay not what the critics lampooned it for, nor worth the high praises heaped upon it either.

When one reads the synopsis of the anime, they will automatically feel interested. The idea seems very new, and different. It also makes you curious to know what will happen next. And for the first two episodes, it kept getting more and more interesting.
Until you realise that the 'plot' is completely unrelated to the execution.
story: 2/10
As mentioned in the synopsis, apathetic middle aged dude gets reincarnated to a little orphan girl by a pissed off 'God', because somehow this way will show him that God exists, and make him grateful, he then gets into this tough world but discovers that there is some sort ofmagic(?) that people fight with, and that he had amazing, unique powers.


Well, I had many problems:


My first problem was how irrelevant the whole reincarnation into a lilo was. He volunteers to enter the army at the age of 8 (no questions) and goes on to become better and better. Having already been an apathetic person, this helped him in being a 'merciless' soldier. and his past life also helped him, but is that all that there is to the whole reincarnation process? We get to rarely see 'God' or 'X Being' in limited scenes where he says empty words that mean nothing, but somehow fuels Tanya to 'overcome obstacles', I have 2 questions:


1. Isn't talking to him acknowledging the fact that he exists?

2. How can she not believe in God, yet falsely pray to somehow make her magic work? made no sense.


It was a great disappointment to see that the reincarnation was only made so that we'd see how the dude seemed very wise in her other life. [as Tanya] 

While the first 2 episodes seem greatly interesting and different, the anime just falls into a very normal series about war. (No right or wrong, patriotism, fighting solely for one's country and following authority) The whole trying-to-be-badass-and-challenge-what-is-calling-himself-a-god- could have easily been avoided. It added nothing to the plot but explaining why a ten year old is leading war. 


My second problem was the fact that Tanya was a fucking lilo. Her being a lilo is a hit or miss, a hit where you think this is brand new and different, interesting to see a 10 year old bossing everyone, or a miss where it's very creepy and offsetting, and also where you cannot believe how everyone acted like it was completely normal and ok for an 8 year old to join the army and beat others all by herself. I don't know about you, but I don't think it was normal back in 1942 (her being a mage doesn't justify anything.) 


I also did not really understand the usage of magic, there is little to no details about it. It was unnecessary and can completely be thrown in the garbage. In the series, some humans have 'magic abilities' which can help the country in war, so scientists create some flying shoes and boxes which 'mages' can fly with to fight enemies. They can also protect themselves and, while using very normal guns, shoot very non-normal bullets. Now don't ask me why people who can use magic need rifles and bullets to begin with, because I cannot give you an answer. It felt like the 'magic' was only put there in an attempt to make the anime look cooler. We never know any kinds or types, any details, what can make it weaker or stronger, when it started existing, its abilities. We know nothing at all.


BUUUUUUUT, the anime *is* entertaining. At one point it did feel repetitive and boring, but for the most part it was greatly engaging. I think it would have been much better had the protagonist been a normal aged character, or if the reincarnation thingy was of any relevance to the plot.


Characters: 5/10


Tanya wasn't a very bad character. Staying in her/his head was quite entertaining and the thought progess was enlightening, but I only felt that the show was about her, which was of no problem at all, but left me forgetting all other characters. I just found her, or him, a little too smart. It's not like he was a General in the military in his past life, he was just a very simple businessman, his talent and abnormal ability of command, training, and combat were just too...unrealistic. His flexibility as well. He adapted rather too quickly to transforming from a middle aged man to an infant girl, he did not even blink. 


my problem with the characters was the X being/God. He was very bland and childish, in the very few scenes where he appeared to pause time, it seemed that he was only trying to tease Tanya while failing miserably to 'prove his point.' Such a meaningless character.


The other characters, as mentioned above, are very easily forgettable. The only character worthy of praise was Colonel Sioux, he left quite an impression on me.


Anime Art: 6/10

I divided it 5 for the background and places, and the other 5 for the characters design.

The backgrounds & places are extremely beautiful. I paused the anime more than a couple of times to take screenshots of how mesmerizing most of the scenery looked. What made the rating go low was the characters' design and how bad they were. Tanya and Viktoriya especially looked very, very sloppy. It pained my eyes whenever Viktoriya appeared in any scene.

There is some lazy work in the battles as many scenes are repeated or static, but this did not cause me much of a problem as they did, at the end, entertain me.


Sound: 8/10

Although I didn't feel it was used much, the sound was very good. From the opening and closing themes to the soundtracks and everything in between..


Overall: 5/10

the story and characters' design needed lots of improvement but they did not prevent the series from being an engaging one. Not something I'd regret watching but not something I'd recommend, either.

This is an updated reviews, written when I finished the series.
This was one of the two series I actively watched every week during this winter/spring, the other one being Kono Suba. While Kono Suba never failed to deliver what I wanted, but Youjo Senki started good, and then deteriorated rapidly.
Youjo Senki was a big disappointment. The series started with a great promise, but after first few very interesting episodes devolved into a very boring slog of events that were barely advancing. Initial episodes were amazing. 2 or maybe 3 or them. After that part, the series are not worth watching, unfortunately. 
Detailed breakdown below.
Story:
The premiseof a psychotic little girl serving in an alternative universe equivalent of World War I is very interesting. Opening episodes were interesting too. However, after first opening episodes where the series demonstrated the crazy heroine and antagonist, the show devolved into a slog of drawn out slow events which mostly involved some people talking about this or that aspect of war, without any of the amazing fights. You'll see people talking ,discussing maps, battle plans but barely anything of significance is being said, and events progress very slowly. Another big issue is that Anime seems to be uncertain about what it wants to be and which side it wants to take. It is unclear whether it wants to be sympathetic to protagonist, to the antagonist, or show life of troops under command of Tanya, or perhaps just indifferently show the events and let the viewer decide. So, it jumps all over the place. At one frame it tries to demonize Tanya, then it tries to show her human side, then it shows how expendable the troops are, then it tries to make viewer sympathetic towards them. It is very inconsistent and frustrating to watch as well. The ending was very unsatisfying. 


Art:

Art is quite ugly. It sorta works in movement, but there's absolutely minimum detail on character's faces. While older generals look tolerable, original design of Serebyrakova was pretty much butchered, and even Tanya herself looks worse than the original art. There's CG being used in big battle scenes, it is noticeable, but not too noticeable. The anime also features quite a lot of cost -cutting techniques which become very noticeable in the 2nd half of the season. There are a lot of "talking heads" scenes, "let's slowly pan something while people are talking in background", etc. In the second half of the season I've noticed that all aerial explosions look the same, and it is one thing that can't be unseen. There are a lot of reused sprites there - every single aerial explosion is identical to each other down to the smallest detail.


Sound:

Sound is alright. There are few decent "dark/menasing/heroic" themes there, but they sorta lack punch. They play in background, but are not powerful enough to truly impress.


Character:

Tanya is interesting enough, but she never gets to do much aside from first few episodes. Basically, after the introductional episodes, the anime somehow manages to avoid putting main character into any situation where here character would make any difference. Events sorta unfurl on their own, and Tanya barely gets any opportunity to display her crazy character qualities. The supporting cast are pretty much cardboard cutouts, with maybe one or two generals displaying hints of resemblance of character. 


Enjoyment:

Very frustrating to watch. After first episodes I really liked I sorta kept waiting for more of the same amazing stuff. Except that anime never delivered anything of the sort.


Overall:

The best idea would be to watch first two or three episodes, and then drop the show completely. It'll just drag on and on, without ever delivering similar material.


So, not recommended to watch.
